name: Application Partitioning
description: The information system separates user functionality (including user interface services) from information system management functionality.
supplemental_guidance: The information system physically or logically separates user interface services (e.g., public web pages) from information storage and management services (e.g., database management). Separation may be accomplished through the use of different computers, different central processing units, different instances of the operating system, different network addresses, combinations of these methods, or other methods as appropriate.

rev5.name: Separation of System and User Functionality

attack_techniques.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Separating user-facing functionality from management services through application partitioning limits the impact of privilege escalation exploits by ensuring compromised user-tier components cannot directly access management-tier resources.

attack_techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Application partitioning that isolates public web interfaces from backend management systems contains drive-by compromise impact, preventing adversary pivot from compromised user-facing components to administrative services.

attack_techniques.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Separating public-facing application interfaces from internal management functionality ensures that exploitation of user-accessible components does not grant direct access to administrative systems or databases.

attack_techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Application partitioning that isolates user interface processing from management services limits the impact of client-side exploitation by preventing compromised user-tier components from accessing privileged management functions.

attack_techniques.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Separating user functionality from system management through physical or logical partitioning limits lateral movement from exploited user-facing services to management infrastructure on separate network segments.

attack_techniques.name: Exploitation for Defense Evasion
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Application partitioning ensures that defense evasion exploits targeting user-facing components cannot directly compromise management-tier security controls operating on separate, isolated infrastructure.

attack_techniques.name: Exploitation for Credential Access
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Separating authentication management from user interface services ensures that credential access exploits targeting user-facing components cannot directly reach credential stores on management-tier systems.

attack_techniques.name: Escape to Host
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Application partitioning that separates containerized user workloads from container management infrastructure limits the impact of container escape by isolating user-tier containers from management-tier orchestration components.
